item.title: Our Story
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
In 2006, Elaine Tuell and Bill Kendall attended a wedding that incorporated a unity sand ceremony. Since they had just gotten engaged and were planning to get married a year and half later on the beach in South Lake Tahoe, they thought a unity sand ceremony would be a great addition to a beach wedding.
The couple spent weeks looking for a frame that would hold the unity sand as well as a photo, but couldn't find one. They ended up building one of their own. After a bit of trial and error they came up with a sand frame that they were excited to include in their wedding. After the ceremony, dozens of friends, family and even vendors asked them about the sand frame. It dawned on them that other engaged couples were probably searching unsuccessfully for a sand frame just as they had done.
Bill and Elaine decided they had stumbled onto a business idea that would help couples reduce the stress of creating their perfect day, incorporate the most unique sand ceremony vessel into their own union and keep a lasting memory intact forever. The concept of The Forever Frame was born. Now, as wonderful as their frame was during the ceremony, afterward was a different story. The frame leaked sand, the sand colors mixed together and there was no way to exchange the photo with one of the ceremony without dumping out the sand entirely. If they were going to share this wonderful idea with others they would need to perfect the concept. They figured out what worked, what didn't and what was missing.
Several prototypes later, The Forever Frame was perfected. We invite you to symbolize your unity with a stunning and contemporary sand ceremony. As you pour your sand into The Forever Frame, the colors will join together in a beautiful formation, never to be replicated. Just as your union can never be separated, neither can the grains of sand.

item.title: Welcome!

In 2006, Elaine Tuell and Bill Kendall attended a wedding that incorporated a unity sand ceremony. Since they had just gotten engaged and were planning to get married a year and half later on the beach in South Lake Tahoe, they thought a unity sand ceremony would be a great addition to a beach wedding.
The couple spent weeks looking for a frame that would hold the unity sand as well as a photo, but couldn't find one. They ended up building one of their own. After a bit of trial and error they came up with a sand frame that they were excited to include in their wedding.
After the ceremony, dozens of friends, family and even vendors asked them about the sand frame. Bill and Elaine decided they had stumbled onto a business idea that would help couples reduce the stress of creating their perfect day, incorporate the most unique sand ceremony vessel into their own union and keep a lasting memory intact forever. The concept of The Forever Frame was born.
Now, as wonderful as their frame was during the ceremony, afterward was a different story. The frame leaked sand, the sand colors mixed together and there was no way to exchange the photo with one of the ceremony without dumping out the sand entirely. If they were going to share this wonderful idea with others they would need to perfect the concept. They figured out what worked, what didn't and what was missing. Several prototypes later, The Forever Frame was perfected.

item.title: The Forever Frame
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
Our unique, patented design prevents the sand from mixing to ensure lasting memories. Don't let your sand become all mixed up in a vase. Use our frame to keep your memories flawless...forever.
  • Sealed sand chamber prevents sand from  escaping.
  • Keeper Plate included to lock sand in place during transport.
  • Removable rear glass allows picture to be changed without disturbing the sand design.
  • Offered in Black, White & Cherry Stain.
What would you put in your Forever Frame?  Chime in and leave us your ideas!  Memories from a destination sand ceremony, anniversary celebration, Prom?  You'll love how easy it is to change photos also, allowing you to showcase your memorable photos. Contact us for more information on The Forever Frame - www.theforeverframe.com.  We look forward to having you as a customer and helping you preserve your special memories.

item.title: Preserve your Grad's Memories
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
Do you have a son, daughter or grandkids graduating from High School or College?  The Forever Frame isn't just a wonderful gift for couples getting married.  It can also make a unique and memorable graduation present.  Your graduate can make it theirs personally by adding memories they wish to preserve from their school years.  Pour sand in representing the school colors, and add other available options to make it personally theirs - a one-of-a kind gift! Why go to the Mall looking for a special gift for your grad - contact us today for more details on getting your very own Forever Frame for their memorable occasion!  See our website at www.theforeverframe.com for more details or feel free to contact us today!  We look forward to assisting you with your gift shopping needs.  Why waste money going to the mall - just give us a call!

item.title: Customer Service is our Priority
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded: We love sharing our customer's testimonials with you.  Excellent customer service is our number one goal, along with complete product satisfaction. Our frame and business will always have loving energy and positive customer relationships.  We intend to be the primary provider of high quality sand frames with a Forever Frame in every household displaying a unique, personal, lasting memory. Scott, We had an absolute perfect day.  It was the best decision we could've made by choosing a destination wedding.  I also have to tell you how much we appreciated your customer service and helpfulness in our scram for a unity frame.  IT turned out amazing and we had sooo many compliments on it.  I cannot Thank you enough for taking the extra time to help us out in order to make our day more special. As you can see in the pictures it turned out really well. The people who packed it up for me didn't settle the sand down even prior to placing the lock in place so it got mixed a little but overall it is perfect.  As I said, we have had many compliments and you will probably get a few more clients because of it.  Thanks so much for everything.  These are some snap shots from friends.  We have not received all pictures yet from our photographer but I hope this will help you out a little.  If you would like more I will gladly send them.  Thanks again for everything. Great product for a perfect day! Angie

item.title: Honoring the Blended Family in Your Wedding Ceremony
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
Extend Your Vows to Include Your Children

  I came across this great post, which was focusing on how to bring your children into your wedding ceremony, be it your first or not, to make them feel a part of the unity celebration.  I've included a quick excerpt and you can click the link below to read the full article.  The Forever Frame can help you when trying to find ways to include your children in the ceremony. Buy separate sand vessels for the children and have their name(s) etched on the vessel.  They can join in when it comes time to pour the sand into the frame, helping to create the beautiful colored pattern.  A forever memory will be flawlessly preserved as a commemoration of your celebration of love!

................................

There is no greater gift than the love that makes two people one. To behold this love blossoming between two hearts is always a joy, and to behold the vows of lovers as they take each to the other, throughout all the
changes of life, is a glorious moment of the soul. It speaks of the great conviction by which people mutually rely upon and believe in one another. In a world where faith often falls short of our expectations, it is a wonderful tribute to two people to see them joining hands and hearts in perfect faith. Into this legacy, BRIDE and GROOM come now to be united, joined by CHILD and CHILD who are here affirming the love between them and their father, and affirming their acceptance of BRIDE into their lives as advisor, guide, and friend. By joining together in this ceremony of love, they four are saying yes to love, yes to caring, and yes to the family. This celebration is the outward token of a sacred and inward union of hearts, which the church may bless and the state make legal, but which neither the state nor church can create or annul, for this union is created by the loving purpose and kept by the abiding will of BRIDE, GROOM, CHILD, and CHILD, as they begin life anew from this time. http://www.associatedcontent.com/article/20628/honoring_the_blended_family_in_your_pg2.html?cat=41   
 

Elaine Kendall 
Owner 
 o: 800. 243. 0834   
 m: 480. 650. 9634  
 www.theforeverframe.com

item.title: Destination Weddings - A Trend or Here to Stay?
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded: I found this great post about destination weddings with lots of good points to consider - who pays for the guests to travel and accommodations, how many guests, and more.  I hope you enjoy reading it and it gives you some good points to ponder if you're considering a destination wedding for your celebration of love.  Click the link below to read the post. The Forever Frame was designed specifically with Destination weddings and sand ceremonies in mind.  It was born out of our search for a frame to use for our sand ceremony.  The Forever Frame was born in 2006, when Elaine Tuell and Bill Kendall attended a wedding that incorporated a unity sand ceremony. Since they had just gotten engaged and were planning to get married a year and half later on the beach in South Lake Tahoe, they thought a unity sand ceremony would be a great addition to a beach wedding. The couple spent weeks looking for a frame that would hold the unity sand as well as a photo, but couldn't find one. They ended up building one of their own. After a bit of trial and error they came up with a sand frame that they were excited to include in their wedding. After the ceremony, dozens of friends, family and even vendors asked them about the sand frame. It dawned on them that other engaged couples were probably searching unsuccessfully for a sand frame just as they had done. Bill and Elaine decided they had stumbled onto a business idea that would help couples reduce the stress of creating their perfect day, incorporate the most unique sand ceremony vessel into their own union and keep a lasting memory intact forever. The concept of The Forever Frame was born. Now, as wonderful as their frame was during the ceremony, afterward was a different story. The frame leaked sand, the sand colors mixed together and there was no way to exchange the photo with one of the ceremony without dumping out the sand entirely. If they were going to share this wonderful idea with others they would need to perfect the concept. They figured out what worked, what didn't and what was missing. Several prototypes later, The Forever Frame was perfected. We invite you to symbolize your unity with a stunning and contemporary sand ceremony. As you pour your sand into The Forever Frame, the colors will join together in a beautiful formation, never to be replicated. Just as your union can never be separated, neither can the grains of sand. What do you think - are destination weddings a hot trend here to stay, or a passing trend?  Join in the conversation and leave us a comment.  Of course, if you have any questions about the frame and the customization features, please contact us.  Thanks for stopping by. http://www.superweddings.com/destination_weddings.html Elaine Kendall Owner o: 800. 243. 0834 m: 480. 650. 9634 www.theforeverframe.com

item.title: Testimonials
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
We're always excited when we receive notes of thanks from our customers. We're receiving orders from Australia, Scotland, England and Ireland.  This is so amazing! We have shaped our business around forming honest relationships with our customers. We will never use sneaky sales tactics or hot-buttons to solicit couples as many salespeople will do. Whatever works best for you makes us happy. This business started because I was a bride planning my own destination beach wedding. I spent months looking for this product and never found it. I ended up making one that was fine at the ceremony but then not so fine in the years to follow. We developed The Forever Frame to remain looking the same as the day you fill it for years to come. We truly appreciate our customers and love helping to make your day as easy and special as possible.

We wanted to share a few of the notes we've received:

Kudos from a client in Scotland... "I just wanted to say that my frame has arrived this morning and I am delighted with it.  It will make a great adition to both our ceremony and also to our home. Thank you for all your help and your great service.  I shall recommend you to anyone else who may be looking for something just a little bit more special for any occasion. Kind Regards, Jayne

==========================================

We were able to make a last minute engraving change for a customer in Chicago.  Here is her email: "Received it today-love it!!! Thank you for making the changes, very happy with it." We're so happy to receive praise from our customers.  It makes our hard work totally worth it!

==========================================

"We absolutely loved our frame!  Thank you so much for your help and kindness."  

                                                          ==========================================

Dianne Kaye - in Australia!
I've just received the frame that will be used in the marriage ceremony for my son & his beautiful fiance in January. I'm so glad I happened to find your site when searching for wedding items online...Huge thankyou's from a very, very happy customer in Australia.

I found this fun post about honeymoon planning basics from The Knot and wanted to share it with you.  With some careful planning and budgeting, you may be able to afford that dream destination for your wedding and honeymoon after all! Of course, purchase your Forever Frame to capture and save those once in a lifetime memories to preserve them flawlessly...forever.  With our special design, the sand that you pour in during your ceremony will not move or sift, even after traveling back home to start your new lives together! Enjoy! http://www.theknot.com.au/honeymoons/honeymoon-basics/honeymoon-planning-basics

item.title: Beach Weddings - A Memorable Venue
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded: Since we're in the dog days of Summer, I thought I'd share this article I was reading.  It's titled 'Summer Wedding, How to Keep Cool'.  There aren't many cool places in July, other than Alaska!  So how do you plan for a Summer wedding, especially with a beach destination?  Will it be sunny and humid, or will a summer storm roll in?  But still, Summer weddings are still a popular time to tie the knot.  So how will you stay cool at your summer wedding? http://blog.wedding-now.com/?p=136 The Forever Frame was designed especially for those summer beach wedding memories.  Our special design keeps your sand from getting mixed up while transporting your memory piece back to your home for display.  You can add a variety of photo sizes inside the frame and they are easily changed out, allowing you to display all of those special photos from your wedding day.  Why put those precious memories in a store bought frame when you could have a Forever Frame?

item.title: Wedding Flowers-Choosing the Right Style for You
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
There is so much involved in planning a wedding.  The dream day you’ve been anxiously awaiting!  Who should you trust?  Should you take on the planning yourself to save money?  How much money should you budget?  The questions are endless. To aid in your decision-making, we’ve decided to post some wedding related tips on our blog.  The Forever Frame is a very flexible, easily customizable product to help you create your unique memories and keep them flawless…forever.

Bouquet Basics

You may think that selecting a bridal bouquet and flowers for your wedding is not that difficult of a task…until you start doing the research and shopping!  How do you know who to trust your flower arrangements with?  After all, what’s a wedding without the flowers.  This is where hiring a wedding planner has its definite advantages.  They work with a trusted set of vendors and venues that they have a relationship with, which ensures that your day will come off without a hitch.

Shapes and Styles

Cascade:  Also called a ‘shower’ bouquet, is very formal and the most traditional bridal bouquet.  It is a waterfall cascade of flowers and is designed to flow and gently cascade downward. Composite:  Looking for a unique look?  This type of bouquet may be your answer.  It is an intricate creation that is made by taking individual petals from flowers and wiring them together on a single stem to create the look of one giant bloom. Hand-Tied:  This is a more relaxed style of bouquet, a variety of blooms that tie in with the wedding theme are wired or loosely gathered together and tied with a satin ribbon or a combination of ribbon and lace. Nosegay:  A combination of elegance and simple style, this bouquet is a densely packed mound of flowers and greenery. Pageant:  This bouquet is also known as a ‘presentation’ bouquet because they are essentially a bunch of long-stemmed flowers that the bride carries cradled in her arms.  It can be simple or elaborate. Pomander:  This is a less traditional bouquet, and it is designed to be a small, compact bloom-covered ball that is generally four to six inches in diameter, and then suspended from a ribbon that is worn around the wrist.  This is a good choice if you want your hands to be free. Posy:  Close to the nosegay, the Posy is smaller in size and perfect for a petite bride with delicate hands or for a bridesmaid’s bouquet.  Select flowers with smaller blooms for this bouquet. Round:  This classic round style bouquet usually consists of large flowers that are loosely arranged.  This is a good choice for a formal wedding or for a bride who wants a more formal look, without going as traditional as the Cascade bouquet. Of course, you always want to consider the style of your gown and what will compliment it.  Lastly, don’t forget to let your personality shine through. Wouldn’t it be fun to preserve flowers from your bouquet and your hubby’s boutonniere in The Forever Frame?

item.title: Bridal Registry Tips
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded: You might not think there’s much to registering so people can purchase the gifts you desire for your wedding.  Don’t rush past this detail without giving it adequate thought though.  What store(s) should you register at – a big local store or a smaller shop that has your favorite items?  Are you letting the store you registered at influence what items you’re picking out, or did you register at a certain big box store because you thought it would be convenient and have items that are reasonably priced?  If so, stop right there.  Take some time to give your gifts some thought.  You’ll be happy you did for years down the road. How Many Stores? This will depend on the size of your guest list.  Generally, a good rule of thumb is between 3 and 5 stores.  You should also consider what kinds of items you are asking for.  You might want to sign up at two to three traditional bridal registry stores, such as Target and Bed Bath and Beyond.  You can then sprinkle in some more non-traditional stores, such as hardware, sports or luggage retailers. How many items should you have on your list?  Should you have a wide range of prices for your guests to choose from?  Do you have plenty of things on your list for those last minute gift-buyers?  These are all questions you should consider.  It’s better to have too many items on your list than not enough and by selecting a wide price range for your guests to choose from makes their shopping and gift choices much easier.  Also remember that your bridal registry will be used to buy shower gifts, so remember to put some personal items on it as well. What’s On the List? Think about your current lifestyle, what your blended lifestyle will look like but remember to contemplate your future lifestyle as well.  Right now you might not be able to imagine giving fancy dinner parties, but perhaps after you get that law degree, your lifestyle will change. Before you go shopping, sit down as a couple and discuss the things you both really want.  You’ve got to discuss colors and designs – something that will make both of you happy.  It’s okay to throw in a few impulse items, but it’s best to go into this venture with an agreed upon list. Remember to go beyond the kitchen, bath and bedroom.  Should you ask for that lawn mower or gas grill you’ve been wanting?  What about high-end electronics, a foosball table, or request money to purchase large appliances? Etiquette Tip Strict etiquette rules are in place on how you tell people about where you have registered.  This should never be included in the wedding invitation, but is okay to include in the shower invitation.  Word of mouth has traditionally been the best way to let people know where you have registered, but in this online world we’re living in, you can also include this information on a wedding web page. Don't forget to add The Forever Frame to your list!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you so much for giving everyone such a splendid possiblity to read from this site. It really is so terrific plus stuffed with a good time for me and my office acquaintances to search your blog more than three times in one week to learn the fresh tips you will have. And definitely, we are certainly impressed with the unique thoughts you serve. Selected two areas in this article are in fact the most efficient I've ever had.

item.title: Wedding Vows – Make Them Personal!
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
Although there are still plenty of traditional wedding ceremonies being planned, it seems that weddings are trending to a more personalized affair.  Couples are finding more and more ways to be creative and let their personalities shine through on their special day.  There are also many fun options available now, such as photo booths, that make this a memorable affair for the guests also.  If you’ve watched the show ‘Four Weddings’, you will hear a lot of emphasis being put on the food and experience for their guests. So is there a good way to decide if you should exchange personal vows in front of your friends and family, or just stick with the traditional ‘repeat after me’ scenario? Here’s a quick thought process to follow when considering personalizing:
  • Meet with your Officiant.  Find out if the church or religion you’re being wed with put any limitations on personalizing vows or how they are placed into the ceremony.  Your officiant will be a good resource for this concern.  They have the luxury of being involved in many weddings and seeing different formats and limitations.  They can also be an excellent resource for ideas if you want to personalize but are drawing a blank on where to start.
  • Interview Each Other.  You know you love each other, but can you put that into concise abbreviated words in front of a crowd?  What if one is excited to profess their love with personal vows and the other is, well, not so excited?  This will be a matter of compromise possibly.  Your wedding day provides much excitement without adding the fear of public speaking!
  • Do Your Research.  Do you share a favorite song, poem or line from a play or movie?  Could that be a launching point for those personalized vows?  Inspiration can come from anywhere, so consider this an exercise in getting to know each other even better!
  • Will You Preview Your Vows with Your Partner?  Will you let the cat out of the bag before the ceremony or do you want it to be totally spontaneous?  Make sure you agree on this issue and set a timeframe to recite the vows.  Are you concerned that your hubby-to-be will only write one sentence while you rattle on about your love for him?
  • Write An Outline.  Set some guidelines so you’re both on the same page.  How long do you want it to be, how personal do you want to get?  These are important considerations.  Three ingredients your vows should contain are a salutation, a declaration of love for your fiancé, and a promise about your marriage.  These will be a good base to build on.
  • Make It Fit.  Your vows should be somewhere between one to three minutes apiece.  Shoot for 375 to 750 words.  Make sure your vows fit your wedding and let your personality shine through as well.  Don’t challenge yourself with new words and vocabulary and definitely sound like yourself.  If you have classical piano and traditional music for your wedding, don’t include rock and roll lyrics in your vows.
  • Practice, Practice, Practice.  I can’t say it enough, practice in front of family, the mirror, time yourself and try to memorize your vows if at all possible.  If you need to have them in writing with you for backup, type them up neatly.  Don’t bring them hand scribbled on a bar napkin!  Ask for feedback from trusted friends who you know will be honest with you.
  • Share.  If you’re not going to share with each other before the ceremony, have a trusted friend or family member listen to both sets of vows and give suggestions if they feel they are not compatible with each other.  That way they can remain a surprise, but still have a feeling that they are in sync with each other.
  • Edit.  If you decide to change anything after you’ve shared, be sure to practice again and retype them.  Don’t forget to grab the revised vows sheet to take with you!
Just remember, determining what you will say and how you will say it can seem like a huge undertaking, but with planning and following these steps, your vows will be a wonderful addition to your remarkable day! We're always so excited when we can be a small part of a couple special day, by helping preserve the memories with The Forever Frame.  Enjoy your wedding!

item.title: Why Hire a Wedding Planner?
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded: Whether you call them a wedding coordinator or planner, these are people who are embedded in the wedding industry and have reliable connections and plentiful resources.  They can share their experiences from past clients’ weddings, both good and bad.  Since they are a wedding planner, then you can count on the fact that they have a patient demeanor, a creative soul and are attentive to details. So how do you find a qualified wedding planner?  Check their credentials to avoid a potential nightmare.  Do they belong to wedding education and certification groups like the Association of Bridal Consultants?  Ask for past client referrals.  Do they have a professional website for you to get an overview of the services that they offer?  Do your homework – you’re putting the overall experience of your wedding day into the hands of the person you decide to hire. Things to consider when considering hiring a planner: Stress-Free Planning:  Estimates are that planning a wedding takes 100 or more hours.  That’s like having a full-time job on top of any other job you may have at the time.  That adds a lot of stress, no matter how fun you think ‘doing it all’ will be in the beginning or how many family members and friends you recruit. Flexibility:  If you would still like to be involved in the orchestration of portions of your wedding, find a planner who is willing to tailor their services around your desires.  Most planners offer different levels of package, from ‘Day of’ to a la carte services, if you find yourself  in over your head and needing help finishing up the details. Efficiency:  They know the industry, local venues and vendors and have trusted people that they maintain successful relationships with.  Because of this, a good planner is able to help you quickly identify your perfect venue, chose your vendors and provide tips regarding details that may have not come to mind yet.  Your time saved will more than make up for the fee paid towards the services of a good wedding coordinator. Style Experts:  Planners are jacks and jills of all things weddings.  They can help you turn your style into realization for your wedding and reception. Maintain Your Budget:  You know how much money you want to spend on your wedding and reception.  A good wedding planner will help you stay within your boundaries. Vendor Referrals:  An experienced planner has a good resource list of trusted vendors that they deal with.  This, once again, is a time saver and avoids potential miscommunications, contract disputes and other pitfalls of hiring vendors that you’re not familiar with.  They have an established relationship with the professionals they use and the vendors want to maintain a positive relationship with the planner.  You win in the end! In the end, whether your budget is limited or large, give serious consideration to hiring a planner to help you make this glorious day a glowing success!  Your wedding should be a joyous occasion – don’t arrive at your wedding exhausted and stressed.  Feel like a guest and enjoy the day with the help of a professional Wedding Coordinator. We're always so happy to be a part of our clients' wedding experience by helping them preserve the memories from their special day with The Forever Frame.  We hope you are enjoying our Friday wedding tips series.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Why Hire a Wedding Planner? « The Forever Frame | Wedding Planning Guide
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] tips regarding details that may have not come to mind yet. … … See more here: Why Hire a Wedding Planner? « The Forever Frame ← What Wedding Planning Tools Are Most Useful? | ATTKA Plus [...]

item.title: Your Wedding and The Dreaded Budget
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
So you’re engaged!  It’s an exciting time in your lives – you’ve found your special someone and you’re going to celebrate your love by getting married.  Now reality sets in!  Planning all of those details involved in making your dream wedding a reality.  You start making a ‘to do’ list and start feeling overwhelmed.  So many details! How much will it cost to cover all of the bills? The first thing to do in this planning process is decide what your wedding budget is going to be, including everything:  dress, wedding officiant, music, reception center, food, flowers and anything else you want to include in your special day.  Even though a wedding coordinator will add more money to your budget, their expertise and knowledge of a variety of venues and vendors will ultimately save you hours, time and money in the end.  They are experts at helping you create your dream day while staying within your real budget. Here’s a handy chart showing a traditional budget breakdown.  Start with your determined budget and use a calculator to figure out the percentages for each expense.  As you purchase or contract each item, write it down and keep a running total of the amount actually spent.  It should be somewhere close to the percentage you determined you wanted to spend on that item.  Of course, the following percentages are just suggestions and if you want to spend more on one category than another, then simply adjust the percentages. The most important thing to remember is that sticking to your budget by keeping a running total of your expenses will help you avoid any stressful surprises and will help you create the wedding of yours dreams without breaking the bank.
Come back for the second part to this post next Friday – Who Pays, How to Pay and Tipping Cheat Sheet.

"Love means not ever having to say you're sorry." ~ Erich Segal
I have been reading through your web site each time I receive a opportunity...and I just wanted to tell you how much I enjoy it! I have appreciation for your experience to this subject!

Do you want to make an investment in your wedding and reception party that might otherwise be used to make a large purchase that you may need – a car, a down payment on a home, a healthy nest egg for your future family? This should be a mutual agreement and it’s important to be honest and understand each others expectations and feelings. In last Friday’s post, a handy chart was included to help you determine what percentages things such as flowers, your reception or transportation will take out of your wedding budget. See it here – Part I. [...]

item.title: Your Wedding and the Dreaded Budget-II
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
Continuing with our post from last Friday, discussing how to set a budget and stick to it while still having your dream wedding, consider that according to The Wedding Report, a company that tracks wedding statistics, the average price of weddings in 2010 ranged from $20,000 to $22,000.  That's a large investment, so put careful consideration into your budget for your dream day and stick to it to avoid a sour taste in your pocketbook after the party is over. Be realistic about what you can afford.  Do you want to make an investment in your wedding and reception party that might otherwise be used to make a large purchase that you may need - a car, a down payment on a home, a healthy nest egg for your future family?  This should be a mutual agreement and it's important to be honest and understand each others expectations and feelings.  In last Friday's post, a handy chart was included to help you determine what percentages things such as flowers, your reception or transportation will take out of your wedding budget.  See it here - Part I.

Who Pays?

Traditionally the bride's family pays all of the wedding costs, from large expenses like the reception venue and transportation to the small fees like wedding favors.  Tradition isn't always followed though, so sit down and determine with the families who wants to contribute towards what.  There is no hard rule on who pays - the key is working out a payment system that works for all the parties involved.

How to Pay?

Once the decision has been made on who's paying for what and how much you'll spend, the next step is to plan on how to handle the transactions.  You could treat the whole process like a business and open up a specific email account to track wedding vendor correspondence that may include important documents like contracts.  Set up a separate bank account that you will deposit your wedding funds into, which will give you a better picture of where you're at on your expenses and you won't be tempted to dip into money that would normally be reserved for bills in your regular account.  If you have some time before your wedding day arrives, designate a specific amount to deposit into your 'wedding account' each paycheck.  Take your determined budget and break it down into how many weeks you have before your wedding to come to an amount to tuck away. It's safer to set up a checking account than to pay with a credit card.  It's just too tempting to go 'a little over budget' and have the worry after the party is over on how you will pay that amount you went over by.

Financial Expectations

Regardless of who's paying the expenses, you will have to keep track of when deposits, fees and payments are due.  If you're a whiz on Excel, set up a spreadsheet as you sign contracts and book vendors and venues to help you keep track of details.  This will give you an easy way to track all of the details, deadlines and money budgeted and spent.

Showing Your Gratitude

Tipping is always up to your discretion, but here are some suggestions:

item.title: 12 Month Wedding Planning Guide
item.dc:creator: theforeverframe
item.content:encoded:
TWELVE MONTHS
  • Choose the date and time for wedding and rehearsal.
  • Purchase Arizona Weddings Magazine and register on www.arizonaweddings.com.
  • Create a wedding email account.
  • Create a wedding website online so family can share.
  • Decide on style – whether a formal event with a sit-down dinner or an afternoon in the gardens.
  • Choose color scheme.
  • Review your budget.  Ask both sets of parents for advice if they’re paying for any or all of the occasion.
  • Select wedding and reception sites.
  • Make appointment with the officiant to learn about pre-marital requirements.
  • Plan the guest list to get a rough count.
  • Choose bridesmaids/groomsmen and ushers.
  • Research honeymoon spots.
  • Interview wedding planners (if you are using one).
  • Shop for gown and headpiece.
  • Book the musicians for ceremony and reception.
  • Interview photographers, videographers, caterers and florists.
NINE MONTHS
  • Announce engagement in newspaper.
  • Select dress for bridal attendants.
  • Start shopping for men’s wedding attire.
  • Decide on the caterer, photographer and videographer.
  • Book a florist and choose arrangements.
  • Register for gifts at bridal registries of choice.
  • Select transportation for ceremony and reception.
SIX MONTHS
  • Order dress and accessories, including veil, gloves and shoes; schedule delivery date.
  • Help m others select and coordinate their dresses.
  • Reserve any rental equipment such as tables, chairs and tent (if you’re marrying at home or in unfurnished space).
  • Choose baker – order wedding cake and groom’s cake.
  • Shop for your trousseau.
  • Select your wedding invitations, envelopes and thank-you cards.
  • Scout around for accommodations for out-of-town guests.
  • Plan the rehearsal dinner.
  • Research marriage license requirements.
  • Choose favors.
  • Confirm honeymoon plans (compile necessary documents, passports, visas, etc.)
  • Finalize guest list.
THREE TO FOUR MONTHS
  • Choose the ceremony music.
  • Talk over reception music with band or DJ.
  • Discuss menu details with caterer.
  • Confirm out-of-town guest accommodations.
  • Order wedding rings and arrange for engraving.
  • Meet with a premarital counselor.
  • Visit officiant and review vows, readings, and music.
  • Select and reserve men’s attire.
  • Address invitations and announcements.
TWO MONTHS
  • Mail invitations.
  • Plan a trial run with headpiece and makeup.
  • Make wedding day hair appointment.
  • Confirm ceremony details.
  • Arrange rehearsal and dinner plans.
  • Draw up map to ceremony and reception site.
  • üomplete proper documents for changing your name.
ONE MONTH
  • Obtain marriage license.
  • Pick up rings and check engraving.
  • Confirm details with the florist, caterer, entertainers and officiant.
  • Notify the newspaper with wedding announcement and photograph.
  • Schedule final dress fitting for you and for your attendants.
  • Buy gifts for attendants, flower girl, ring bearer, fiancée, parents (and anyone else who helped make the wedding extra special).
  • Finish trousseau shopping.
  • Plan pre-wedding attendants’ party.
TWO WEEKS
  • Confirm rehearsal dinner plans.
  • Find out about gown, bouquet, and/or cake preservation.
  • Contact guests who did not RSVP to invitations.
  • Arrangement seating plan and write place cards.
  • Break in wedding shoes at home – scuff the bottom, walk around in them.
  • Meet with photographer and videographer – submit list of must-take shots.
ONE WEEK
  • Pick up dress or have it delivered.
  • Host bridesmaids’ party.
  • Pack for honeymoon.
  • Confirm travel arrangements – if traveling abroad, purchase small amount of local currency.
  • Write toast for rehearsal dinner and wedding reception.
  • Arrangement for facial and other beauty treatments.
  • Give assignments to wedding party members, remind them of rehearsal details.
  • Confirm transportation details.
  • Notify caterer of the final guest count.
  • Review timetables and details with vendors.
DAY BEFORE
  • Give wedding announcements to an attendant to mail after the wedding.
  • Verify transportation to and from the wedding ceremony.
  • Deliver gift baskets if you have them.
  • Have manicure and pedicure.
  • Attend ceremony rehearsal.
  • Hold rehearsal dinner and hand out special gifts to wedding party.
  • Prepare tip envelopes and arrange for someone to distribute them the day of.
WEDDING DAY!
  •  Eat breakfast.
  •  Arrange to get checked in and have luggage delivered to your hotel.
  •  Get hair and makeup done.
  •  Get dressed.
  •  Switch your engagement ring to your right hand.
  •  Relax and enjoy the day!

item.title: Responsibility Reminders
item.dc:creator: helperbs
item.content:encoded:
It is important that your attendants know what they’re responsible for and also that you pick your bridal party with these things in mind. When you ask your friends and family to be a part of your wedding, they will probably answer “yes!” without giving it much thought. So before you ask them to commit, avoid potential issues and let them know just what they’re in for if they agree to be a part of your special day.

Bridal Party Obligations

Maid or Matron of Honor

Your maid or matron of honor (MOH) is really your right hand ma’am and your second in command. She should be a person who is closest to you, whether it’s your sister or your best friend. Be careful not to hurt the feelings of those closest to you when you make your pick – this can be a potentially touchy situation. So what does a MOH do? Here’s a list of traditional duties: • Assist the bride with any pre-wedding tasks. • Coordinate the bridesmaids for dress shopping and fittings. • Purchase her own attire for the wedding. • Host a shower or bachelorette party with the bridesmaids, and attend all other pre-wedding events. • Help the bride dress on the wedding day. • Arrange the bride’s dress at the altar and hold the bridal bouquet if necessary. The MOH is also responsible for holding the groom’s ring during the ceremony if necessary. • Sign the marriage license as one of the two witnesses. • Give a toast at the reception at the bride’s request. • Assist the bride with any tasks after the reception. Any duties that your MOH is willing to pitch in and take care of are greatly appreciated. Dropping your bridal gown off at the dry cleaners while you whisk away on your honeymoon or taking your bouquet to be preserved – the duties don’t end when the wedding is over!

Best Man

The honor of Best Man is usually bestowed on the groom’s brother or closest friend, but groom have sometimes opted to have their father as their best man. As the maid of honor is the bride’s right-hand ma’am, the best man plays a similar role for the groom. • Assist the groom with any pre-wedding tasks. • Coordinate the bachelor party with the groomsmen. • Rent or purchase his own formal wear. • Help the groom dress and take care of any last-minute details before the ceremony. • Keep the bride’s wedding ring safe until it is requested during the ceremony. • Sign the marriage license as one of the two witnesses. • Propose a toast to the newlyweds during the reception. • At the groom’s request, the best man may hand sealed envelopes containing payments to servers, officiants and other wedding vendors. • Escort the newlyweds to their limousine or car or maybe serve as the chauffeur to their final destination after the reception. • Assist with the return of tuxedo rentals after the wedding. As with the MOH, the Best Man’s duties don’t necessarily end when the party’s over. He may be asked to help transport the gifts from the reception to their final destination.

Bridesmaids

You should first decide how many people you want to manage in your bridal party. The more people you invite to be a part of your ceremony, the more people and projects you may end up managing. Then there’s always the personality mixes to take into consideration and friends’ feelings. Bridemaids can be called on for any number of duties also, including assisting the bride with pre-wedding tasks and helping with any last-minute details before the ceremony.

Groomsmen

Guys look to their closest buddies and family members when looking for their groomsmen. When your bride is deciding on the number of bridesmaids, make sure you have enough friends to equal her numbers! The Groomsmen may be asked to help plan a bachelor party, assist the groom or best man with any pre-wedding chores, or may be busy decorating the getaway car.

Ushers

When considering how many ushers to recruit, think about how many wedding guests you will be inviting and then decide how many ushers you may need to keep the traffic moving while people are arriving and getting seated. While in the past ushers have been traditionally men, women are serving as wedding ushers. The traditional duties of an usher may include attending all pre-wedding events, assisting the bride and groom with any last-minute details before the ceremony, seating the guests before the ceremony, or unrolling the aisle runner in preparation for the bride’s entrance. Lastly, don’t expect too much of your helpers – that’s a sure way to put a strain on family and friends’ relationships. Also remember that they are not wedding planning professionals, so you must gracefully accept their assistance no matter how it turns out.  Happy weddings!
